column1: Unecha (Russian: Уне́ча) is a town and the administrative center of Unechsky District in Bryansk Oblast
column3: located on the Unecha River (the Dnieper's basin) 140 kilometers (87 mi) southwest of Bryansk
column4: the administrative center of the oblast.

column1: Town status was granted to it in 1940.From 1936 to 1951 Unecha was the home station for the Unecha motive branch of the Belarusian railway.
From September 1943 to March 1944 the Directorate of the Belarusian railway was situated in the town.

column3: 708 Jews were living in Unecha. The town was occupied by the German army in the middle of August 1941. A large number of Jews managed to flee to the east before the Germans’ arrival.

column2: the Jews were distinguished and forbidden to leave the town. In October 1941
column3: all the Jews were confined to a closed ghetto
column4: where they stayed till its liquidation in mid-March 1942. Due to harsh living conditions and hunger
column5: many Jews died before the liquidation. Hundred of them were executed and group of Roma from another village were murdered alongside the Jews on this day.

column2: Unecha serves as the administrative center of Unechsky District. As an administrative division
column5: incorporated within Unechsky District as Unechsky Urban Administrative Okrug. As a municipal division
column6: Unechsky Urban Administrative Okrug is incorporated within Unechsky Municipal District as Unechskoye Urban Settlement.
